titleStmt.title: More true and exceeding joyfull newes from Ireland, or, The victorious proceedings of the Protestants in the Neweries, and in the north parts of Ireland, from the 11. of Aprill, to this present. 1642. Shewing, in a most true, and reall relation, the manner of three glorions [sic] and renowned battels, fought by these worthy pillars of the Protestant religion; following. The first, by the Lord President of Munster, in the north parts of Ireland, neere Donne, Aprill the 11. 1642. The second, by these two worthy commanders of our army, Sir Richard Greenvill and Sir Charles Coote, in the Neweries, Aprill, the 13. 1642. The third, by the noble and heroick champion, Captaine Marro, Aprill 14. Lately set forth out of Holborne, London, with 100. men. Brought over by the last post, Aprill 18. 1642. Likewise, the copie of a letter sent from Ireland, to a worthy gentleman in London, and read in the Honourable House of Commons. It is ordered, that this be forthwith printed. Hen. Elsynge, Cleric. Parl. D. Com.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 8 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 6 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

availability.p: To the extent possible under law, the Text Creation Partnership has waived all copyright and related or neighboring rights to this keyboarded and encoded edition of the work described above, according to the terms of the CC0 1.0 Public Domain Dedication (http://creativecommons.org/publicdomain/zero/1.0/). This waiver does not extend to any page images or other supplementary files associated with this work, which may be protected by copyright or other license restrictions. Please go to https://www.textcreationpartnership.org/ for more information about the project.

titleStmt.author: R. H.
England and Wales. Parliament.

notesStmt.note: "Very good news from Ireland" p. 7 signed R. H.
Reproduction of the original in the British Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: MORE TRUE AND Exceeding Joyfull Newes FROM IRELAND, OR, The Victorious Proceedings of the Prote≈øtants in the Neweries, and in the North parts of Jreland, From the 11. of Aprill, To this pre≈øent. 1642.
SHEWING, In a mo≈øt true, and Reall Relation, the manner of three Glorious and Renowned Battels, fought by the≈øe Worthy Pillars of the Prote≈øtant Religion; following.

list.item: The fir≈øt, by the Lord Pre≈øident of Mun≈øter, in the North parts of Ireland, neere Donne, Aprill the 11. 1642.
The ≈øecond, by the≈øe two Worthy Commanders of our Army, Sir Richard Greenvill and Sir Charles Coote, in the Neweries, Aprill, the 13. 1642.
The third, by the Noble and Heroick Champion, Captaine Marro, Aprill 14. Lately ≈øet forth out of Holborne, London, with 100. Men.

div.p: Brought ever by the la≈øt Po≈øt, Aprill 18. 1642.
Likewi≈øe, the Copie of a Letter ≈øent from Ireland, to a worthy Gentl ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ in London, and r ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ d in the Honourable Hou≈øe of COMMONS.
It is Ordered, That this be forthwith Printed.

p.hi: H ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ , El≈øynge, Cleric. Parl. D. Com.

div.head: More True, and Exceeding Joyfull Newes from JRELAND.
div.p: SInce my la≈øt Letter, I have ≈øent you the≈øe joyfull Occurrences, being all the proceedings, which pa≈ø≈øed from Aprill the 12. 1642. To this pre≈øent.

Vpon the 12 day of Aprill, the Lord Pre≈øident of Mun≈øter fought: a great Battle with the Rebels in the North parts of Jreland, hazarding his owne per≈øons very dangerou≈øly, by rea≈øon of his couragions and Heroick Spirit bringing up his men ≈øo valiantly, he him≈øelfe being fore-mo≈øt in the Re ‚Ä¢ re, but after 2. or. 3. value of Shot, withdrew him≈øelfe into the mid≈øt of his Army.

It is credibly reported, that he with 700. men, hath fought again≈øt 3000 of the Rebels, the fight la≈øting for the ≈øpace of five houres, and hath ≈ølaine 1300 of them, and tooke foure≈øcore pri≈øoners, ≈øome being Commanders of great Note, and hath likewi≈øe wonne the ≈øtrong Ca≈øtle of Carnow, leaving a ≈øtrong Garri≈øon in the ≈øame.
After this, he marched to his owne Quarters againe, and doth intend very ≈øuddenly, to ≈øet forth, to ≈øcoure tho≈øe parts.

But upon the 13. day of Aprill was a joyfull day with us, when the Earle of Ormond with 500 Foote and 100 hor≈øe, gave Battle again≈øt two thou≈øand Rebels, neare to the City of Youghall, who had entrenched them≈øelves very ≈øtrongly; and after a bloody Battle, burnt them out of their Quarters, they retreating backe with the lo≈ø≈øe of 800 men, leaving great ≈øtore of good Pillage behind them, of our ≈øide were ≈ølaine not above 50. at the mo≈øt, all Common Souldiers.

On the 14. day of Aprill, Sr. Richarh Greenvill,
Sr. Charles Coote, and Captaine Marro, ≈øet forth with 5000. men from our City, and marched towards the Neweriis, where they had Battle given them immediately by 12000 Rebels, but they were re≈øi≈øted mo≈øt valiantly by them againe, ≈øo that a long and tedious Battle did in≈øue, Captaine Marro bringing up the Reare, gave Fire ≈øo thicke upon them, that in the fir≈øt incounter were ≈ølain of the Rebels 300. our men ≈øeeing them fall ≈øo thicke before them were mightyly encouraged, ≈øo that they mo≈øt pui≈ø≈øantly ≈øent the dreadfull Bullets among≈øt them, ≈øo that by that meanes the Rebels retreated backe, for the ≈øpace of halfe a Mile, our men pur≈øuing them very clo≈øe, ≈ølew 200 of them in theire retreat whereupon the Rebels in≈øtantly pre≈øented them≈øelves in a faire Battalia Order, ≈øo that there did begin another hot Skirmi≈øh for the ≈øpace of foure houres, where there were ≈ølain of the Rebels 500. more, of our ≈øide three≈øcore, the Battle then ending, the Rebels retreated backe, leaving great ≈øtore of Pillage behind them

Then Captaine Marro, with the con≈øent of Sir Richard Greenvill, and Sr. Charles Coote,
drew out 1000 men from the maine Body, taking with him foure pieces of Ordnance, and upon the 14. of this pre≈øent Moneth, marched towards Wallen Ca≈øtle, foure Miles di≈øtant from the Army, where he gave them a ≈øuddaine a≈ø≈øault, and beate downe a great wall of the Ca≈øtle, which put the Rebels into a great perplexity, neverthele≈ø≈øe they with the be≈øt Power and Strength they had, gave Battell to him, and after the ≈øpace of foure houres fight, they ≈øounded a Parley, Captaine Marro ≈øhewing him≈øelfe in the Front, they de≈øiring of him ≈øome time to prepare them≈øelves for Battell, but he immediately cau≈øed the Drums to beat up, and mounted his Ordnance again≈øt them, ≈øo that after ≈øome time to prepare them≈øelves for Battell, but immediately cau≈øed the Drums to beate up, and mounted his Ordnance again≈øt them, that after ≈øome time he attained the Ca≈øtle, putting all to the Sword that was therein.
Our Army is entred in the Neweries, 15. Miles, and doth intend (God willing) to give them another Battell very ≈øuddenly.

div.head: Very good Newes from Jreland.
div.p: I Have written by the the two la≈øt Po≈øts, and having good Newes, it ≈øhall trot to impart it unto you.

The la≈øt Saturday the Lord Moore and Sir Henry Tuchburne ≈øallyed out of the Towne, and fell upon the Enemies, and drove them out of their Trenches, and rai≈ø'd their Siege, ≈ølew about 350 of their men, and tooke many of their chiefe Officers, and have relieved them≈øelves bravely, and tooke 150 of their Muskets, and a Field full of Pikes, we having lo≈øt, as ≈øome affirme no men. Here are three of our Captaines come by Land, ≈øo that this Newes is true.

Vpon Munday our Forces went out, 4000 Foote and 500 Hor≈øe, they are already within five myles of Tredagh: by the way; Lievtenant Colonell Reade came into our men, and ≈øubmitted, if he had not done it he
could not have fled: he is ≈øent hither, and lodg'd in the Ca≈øtle I doe believe we ≈øhall now get good ≈øtore of Corne out of the Countrey, which will keepe the price from ri≈øing. Our men are not expected home this weeke, pray GOD keepe them ≈øafe: Sir Philimy Oneale was in the Battle, but was faine to flye; and that was not like to ≈øerve turne.

closer.signed: With my true love, I re≈øt: Your affectionate Friend, R. H.

div.p: It is this day Ordered, That this be forthwith Printed.

closer.signed: He. El≈øynge, Cleric. Parl. D. Com.
